Answer: Chinese factories produce goods based on their clients’ specifications. Each order of a certain item come with its own quality specifications which defined by client. Higher quality goods are more costly to make, which in turn increase the retail price. Lower quality goods are cheaper to make, which in turn (sometimes) reduce retail price.The impression that “Made in China" means cheap stuff because Chinese can't make good stuff is very unfair to us. We make stuff. Our clients decide whether they're cheap.In other words, if you're willing to pay us more, we'll make better stuff for you. If youChinese factories produce goods based on their clients’ specifications. Each order of a certain item come with its own quality specifications which defined by client. Higher quality goods are more costly to make, which in turn increase the retail price. Lower quality goods are cheaper to make, which in turn (sometimes) reduce retail price.The impression that “Made in China" means cheap stuff because Chinese can't make good stuff is very unfair to us. We make stuff. Our clients decide whether they're cheap.In other words, if you're willing to pay us more, we'll make better stuff for you. If you're cheap, you get cheap shit.

Answer: Because Chinese factories make things to spec. If you go to a Chinese factory you tell them what you want and they build it.If you want stuff that works, they will build stuff that works but they will charge you more. If you want cheap crap they will quote you a price for cheap crap.It turns out that if you want to make high quality goods you have to brand it as high quality. So Apple goes to a Chinese factory, pays a little extra for quality and then makes a ton of money with branding.It turns out that Chinese companies looked at thus and said heeeeeyyyy we want to make the extra cash from hiBecause Chinese factories make things to spec. If you go to a Chinese factory you tell them what you want and they build it.If you want stuff that works, they will build stuff that works but they will charge you more. If you want cheap crap they will quote you a price for cheap crap.It turns out that if you want to make high quality goods you have to brand it as high quality. So Apple goes to a Chinese factory, pays a little extra for quality and then makes a ton of money with branding.It turns out that Chinese companies looked at thus and said heeeeeyyyy we want to make the extra cash from high quality and branding. Huawei tried this. It was wildly successful, but then the US got annoyed and put sanctions on Huawei.So yeah, China wants to get out of the cheap crap business. However the moment it goes into the high quality business (because China is already making the stuff anyway) the US freaks out and imposes sanctions.The trouble is that if you can build high quality toasters and smart phones then you can build high quality hypersonic missiles and unmanned fighter jets. So the US is trying its hardest to keep China in the cheap crap business but China is pushing back.

Answer: In terms of military technology, China is still about a decade behind the United States of America. However, China is ahead of the United States in other fields including:Producing renewable energy:Currently, China is the worlds leading producer of renewable energy, and largest buyer of solar panels since 2015. By 2013, China could produce up to 378 GW of electricity mainly from hydroelectricity and wind power. In 2017, renewable energy was responsible for 36.6% of China’s total installed electric power capacity.World’s fastest supercomputer:The Tianhe-2 iIn terms of military technology, China is still about a decade behind the United States of America. However, China is ahead of the United States in other fields including:Producing renewable energy:Currently, China is the worlds leading producer of renewable energy, and largest buyer of solar panels since 2015. By 2013, China could produce up to 378 GW of electricity mainly from hydroelectricity and wind power. In 2017, renewable energy was responsible for 36.6% of China’s total installed electric power capacity.World’s fastest supercomputer:The Tianhe-2 is the world’s fastest computer located in the National Supercomputer Center in Guangzhou, China. It took 1300 scientists and engineers to develop! According to TOP500, the Tianhe-2 was the world’s fastest computer for June 2013, November 2013, June 2014, November 2014, and November 2015. In June 2013, it defeated the previous fastest supercomputer, America’s Titan. The Titan achieved 17.59 petaflops, while Tianhe-2 achieved 33.86 petaflops. Furthermore, in June 2013 China possessed 66 of the top 500 supercomputers, while the United States of America had 252. This changed when in June 2016, China increased the total to 168 and overtook the United States who fell to 165.Edit:What are the technologies from China that lead the world?

Answer: Space is far from conquered, there’s travel, habitation, terra-forming, space fabrication, faster than light travel out of the solar system, harnessing wormholes, exobiology, dark matter, astronavigation, life support and suspended animation, space robotics, we’ve got a small start on it and milllenias to go.Oceans are still quite a frontier with not nearly as much known about them or as fully mapped underwater as people assume after thousands of years on top of the water (heck we don’t know that much about lakes, especially really deep ones like Lake Baikal or underground lakes.) While we canSpace is far from conquered, there’s travel, habitation, terra-forming, space fabrication, faster than light travel out of the solar system, harnessing wormholes, exobiology, dark matter, astronavigation, life support and suspended animation, space robotics, we’ve got a small start on it and milllenias to go.Oceans are still quite a frontier with not nearly as much known about them or as fully mapped underwater as people assume after thousands of years on top of the water (heck we don’t know that much about lakes, especially really deep ones like Lake Baikal or underground lakes.) While we can go quite deep quite briefly, we can’t easily get down to the deep ocean floor, let alone the bottom of the Marianas Trench, nor stay there for weeks or years. Underwater habitats, mining colonies, research labs etc. looked like we were going to have in the 1960’s and rapidly advancing from that point to thousands of people living underwater by now so lots of frontier left there.Going really small on anything continues to open new frontiers (nanomaterials, nanotechnologies, biomimicry of insects, subatomic particles, anti-matter, genome analysis, molecular biology, genetic engineering, computer coding, tissue printing, quantum computing, etc.).Going really large we still have very partial understandings of ecosystems, hydrogeology, geology…especially miles deep or in space, weather systems and climates both micro and macro, satellite imagery and new sensors surprise more than they confirm old guesses, all of the other planets and moons in our solar system continue to surprise us while we’ve barely been there at all, much of the insect and sealife is mostly unknown to us as are how plants interact with each other and their environments, what our galaxy is really like let alone what the neighboring galaxies are like or what the nearest stars’ planets are like.How much we know about how the human brain works has been estimated to be doubling ever 5 years since the 1960’s while new tools like MRI’s, CT Scanners, etc. keep opening up new frontiers and destroying old models.There are a lot of frontiers that seem pretty thoroughly explored in entertainment, maybe that’s why it often seems we’re at “the end of history”.
